question: Question 1 Consider the set [latex]S[/latex] of points [latex](x, y) \in  \mathfrak{R}^2[/latex] which minimize the real-valued function [latex]f(x, y) = (x + y - 1)^2 + (x + y)^2[/latex] Which of the following statements is true about the set [latex]S[/latex]?
solution: We are given: [latex]f(x, y) = (x + y - 1)^2 + (x + y)^2[/latex] Step 1: Substitute a single variable Let [latex]u = x + y[/latex] Then, the function becomes: [latex]f(x, y) = (u - 1)^2 + u^2 = u^2 - 2u + 1 + u^2 = 2u^2 - 2u + 1[/latex] Step 2: Minimize [latex]f(u) = 2u^2 - 2u + 1[/latex] This is a quadratic function in [latex]u[/latex] with a positive coefficient, so it has a unique minimum. The minimum occurs at: [latex]u = \frac{-(-2)}{2 \cdot 2} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] So, the function is minimized when [latex]x + y = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] Step 3: Analyze the set [latex]S[/latex] All points [latex](x, y)[/latex] satisfying [latex]x + y = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] will minimize [latex]f(x, y)[/latex]. There are infinitely many such points in [latex]\mathbb{R}^2[/latex]. Final Answer: [latex]\boxed{\text{The number of elements in the set } S \text{ is infinite}}[/latex] Correct Option: (B)

options.A: The number of elements in the set S is finite and more than one.
options.B: The number of elements in the set S is infinite.
options.D: The number of elements in the set S is exactly one.

question: Question 2 Let [latex]v_{1}[/latex] and [latex]v_{2}[/latex] be the two eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues of a [latex]3 \times 3[/latex] real symmetric matrix. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: Step 1: Given that the matrix is a real symmetric matrix. Step 2: A well-known property of real symmetric matrices is that eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues are orthogonal. Step 3: If [latex] \mathbf{v}_1 [/latex] and [latex] \mathbf{v}_2 [/latex] are eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues of a real symmetric matrix, then: [latex] \mathbf{v}_1^T \mathbf{v}_2 = 0 [/latex] This means they are orthogonal. Step 4: Among the given options, option (B) matches this condition. Final Answer: (B) [latex] \mathbf{v}_1^T \mathbf{v}_2 = 0 [/latex]

Then, the system of linear equations [latex]\mathrm{Ax}=\mathrm{b}[/latex] has

Question 5 Consider discrete random variables X and Y with probabilities as follows: [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=0[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=0)=\frac{1}{4}[/latex], [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=1[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=0)=\frac{1}{8}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=0[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=1)=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=1[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=1)=\frac{1}{8}[/latex] Given [latex]\mathrm{X}=1[/latex], the expected value of [latex]\mathrm{Y}[/latex] is
solution: Step 1: Identify the conditional probabilities of [latex] Y [/latex] given [latex] X = 1 [/latex]. From the given: [latex] P(X=1, Y=0) = \frac{1}{8}, \quad P(X=1, Y=1) = \frac{1}{8} [/latex] So, total probability [latex] P(X=1) = \frac{1}{8} + \frac{1}{8} = \frac{1}{4} [/latex] Step 2: Compute the conditional probabilities: [latex] P(Y=0 \mid X=1) = \frac{P(X=1, Y=0)}{P(X=1)} = \frac{\frac{1}{8}}{\frac{1}{4}} = \frac{1}{2} [/latex] [latex] P(Y=1 \mid X=1) = \frac{P(X=1, Y=1)}{P(X=1)} = \frac{\frac{1}{8}}{\frac{1}{4}} = \frac{1}{2} [/latex] Step 3: Compute the expected value: [latex] \mathbb{E}[Y \mid X=1] = 0 \cdot P(Y=0 \mid X=1) + 1 \cdot P(Y=1 \mid X=1) = 0 \cdot \frac{1}{2} + 1 \cdot \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{2} [/latex] Final Answer: (B) [latex] \frac{1}{2} [/latex]

Question 10 Consider a discrete-time linear time-invariant (LTI) system S , where [latex]\mathrm{y}[\mathrm{n}]={S}\{{x}[\mathrm{n}]\}[/latex] Let [latex]S\{\delta[n]\}= \begin{cases}1, & \mathrm{n} \in\{0,1,2\}\\  0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}[/latex] Where [latex]\delta[\mathrm{n}][/latex] is the discrete-time unit impulse function. For an input signal [latex]x[n][/latex], the output [latex]y[n][/latex] is
solution:
The impulse response of discrete-time LTI system is given as [latex]\mathrm{h}(\mathrm{n})=\delta(\mathrm{n})+\delta(\mathrm{n}-1)+\delta(\mathrm{n}-2)[/latex] For an input [latex]\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n})[/latex], the output [latex]\mathrm{y}(\mathrm{n})[/latex] is given by [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{y}(\mathrm{n}) & =\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}) * \mathrm{~h}(\mathrm{n}) \\
& =\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}) *[\delta(\mathrm{n})+\delta(\mathrm{n}-1)+\delta(\mathrm{n}-2)] \\
& =\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n})+\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}-1)+\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}-2)
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 11 Consider a continuous-time signal [latex]\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t})=-\mathrm{t}^{2}\{\mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}+4)-\mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}-4)\}[/latex] Where [latex]u(t)[/latex] is the continuous-time unit step function. Let [latex]\delta(\mathrm{t})[/latex] be the continuous-time unit impulse function. The value of [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) \delta(\mathrm{t}+3) \mathrm{dt}[/latex] is
solution: Given: [latex]\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) = -\mathrm{t}^2 {\mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}+4) - \mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}-4)}[/latex] This represents a time-limited signal that exists only between [latex]t = -4[/latex] and [latex]t = 4[/latex]. Outside this interval, [latex]x(t) = 0[/latex]. Also given: We are to compute the value of the integral: [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) \delta(\mathrm{t}+3) , \mathrm{dt}[/latex] Step 1: Use the sifting property of the delta function: [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \delta(t - t_0) , dt = f(t_0)[/latex] Similarly, [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \delta(t + 3) , dt = f(-3)[/latex] Step 2: Evaluate [latex]x(-3)[/latex] [latex]x(t) = -t^2 {u(t+4) - u(t-4)}[/latex] At [latex]t = -3[/latex], [latex]u(-3 + 4) = u(1) = 1[/latex] and [latex]u(-3 - 4) = u(-7) = 0[/latex] So, [latex]x(-3) = -(-3)^2 (1 - 0) = -9[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) \delta(\mathrm{t}+3) , \mathrm{dt} = x(-3) = -9[/latex]

question:
Question 12 Selected data points of the step response of a stable first-order linear time-invariant (LTI) system are given below. The closest value of the time-constant, in sec, of the system is [latex]\begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline
Time(sec) & 0.6 & 1.6 & 2.6 & 10 & \infty \\
\hline
Output & 0.78 & 1.65 & 2.18 & 2.98 & 3 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution: Step 1: Analyze the step response of a first-order LTI system For a first-order LTI system, the step response is given by: [latex]y(t) = K \left(1 - e^{-t/\tau}\right)[/latex] Where [latex]K[/latex] is the steady-state value (final output), and [latex]\tau[/latex] is the time constant. Step 2: Use the steady-state value The output approaches the steady-state value as [latex]t \to \infty[/latex]. At [latex]t = \infty[/latex], the output is 3, which is the steady-state value (K). Thus, [latex]K = 3[/latex]. Step 3: Relating time and output For a first-order system, the time at which the output reaches [latex]63%[/latex] of the final value is equal to the time constant [latex]\tau[/latex]. So, [latex]y(\tau) = K \left(1 - e^{-1}\right) = 3 \times (1 - e^{-1}) \approx 3 \times 0.632 = 1.896[/latex]. Step 4: Find the closest data point to 1.896 Looking at the given data points, at [latex]t = 1.6 \text{ sec}, y(t) = 1.65[/latex], which is the closest to 1.896. Thus, the time constant [latex]\tau \approx 2 \text{ sec}[/latex]. Final Answer: The closest value of the time constant is [latex]2 \text{ sec}[/latex].

question: Question 13 The Nyquist plot of a strictly stable [latex]G(s)[/latex] having the numerator polynomial as [latex](s-3)[/latex] encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. Which one of the following statements on the closed-loop system shown in figure, is correct?
solution: Given: The Nyquist plot of a strictly stable transfer function [latex]G(s)[/latex] has the numerator polynomial [latex](s - 3)[/latex], and it encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. Step 1: Understand the Nyquist criterion The Nyquist criterion provides a relationship between the open-loop transfer function’s Nyquist plot and the stability of the closed-loop system. According to the Nyquist criterion, the number of encirclements of the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] determines the stability of the closed-loop system. Step 2: Analyze the information given The Nyquist plot encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. The open-loop transfer function is strictly stable, implying that all poles are in the left half of the complex plane. The system's Nyquist plot encircles the critical point [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction. According to the Nyquist criterion, this indicates that the number of right-half-plane poles of the open-loop transfer function is 1. Step 3: Apply the Nyquist criterion for stability The Nyquist criterion states that for the closed-loop system to be stable, the number of encirclements of the point [latex]-1[/latex] must be equal to the number of right-half-plane poles of the open-loop transfer function. Since the Nyquist plot encircles [latex]-1[/latex] once in the anti-clockwise direction, the number of right-half-plane poles is 1. This suggests that the closed-loop system is unstable because the number of encirclements of [latex]-1[/latex] is non-zero, and the system has a pole in the right half of the complex plane. Final Answer: The system is unstable.

options.A: The system stability cannot be ascertained.

question: Question 14 During a power failure, a domestic household uninterruptible power supply (UPS) supplies AC power to a limited number of lights and fans in various rooms. As per a Newton-Raphson loadflow formulation, the UPS would be represented as a
solution: In a power system load-flow analysis: A Slack bus (swing bus) is defined with specified voltage magnitude and angle. It balances the active and reactive power in the network. A PV bus has specified real power [latex]P[/latex] and voltage magnitude [latex]V[/latex], while [latex]Q[/latex] is calculated. A PQ bus has specified real power [latex]P[/latex] and reactive power [latex]Q[/latex], and [latex]V[/latex] and angle [latex]\theta[/latex] are calculated. A PQV bus is not a standard term in load-flow analysis. In this case, the UPS supplies power and maintains the system voltage, effectively acting as the reference. Hence, it is modeled as a Slack bus in Newton-Raphson load-flow formulation.

Question 18 Instrument(s) required to synchronize an alternator to the grid is/are
solution:
To synchronize an alternator with the grid, the following conditions must be satisfied: The terminal voltage of the alternator should match the grid voltage. The frequency of the alternator must be equal to the grid frequency. The phase sequence should be identical. The phase angle difference should be nearly zero at the instant of synchronization. Instruments used to verify these conditions are: (A) Voltmeter:
Used to ensure the voltage of the alternator matches the grid voltage. (B) Wattmeter:
Measures power; not used for synchronization. (C) Synchroscope:
Used to indicate the phase angle and frequency difference between the alternator and the grid. It shows whether the alternator is running fast or slow and when to close the circuit breaker. (D) Stroboscope:
Used to measure rotational speed visually; not used in electrical synchronization.

question: Question 20 A continuous time periodic signal [latex]{x}({t})[/latex] is [latex]x(t)=1+2 \cos 2 \pi t+2 \cos 4 \pi t+2 \cos 6 \pi t[/latex]. If [latex]T[/latex] is the period of [latex]x(t)[/latex], then [latex]\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T}| x(t)| ^{2} dt=[/latex] _________  (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Step 1: Find the period [latex]T[/latex] The signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] consists of cosine terms with frequencies [latex]2\pi, 4\pi, 6\pi[/latex], which correspond to fundamental frequencies [latex]1 , \text{Hz}, 2 , \text{Hz}, 3 , \text{Hz}[/latex]. The period of the signal [latex]T[/latex] is the least common multiple (LCM) of the periods of these individual cosine terms. The period of [latex]2\pi t[/latex] (1 Hz) is [latex]T_1 = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex]. The period of [latex]4\pi t[/latex] (2 Hz) is [latex]T_2 = 0.5 , \text{sec}[/latex]. The period of [latex]6\pi t[/latex] (3 Hz) is [latex]T_3 = \frac{1}{3} , \text{sec}[/latex]. The LCM of [latex]T_1, T_2, T_3[/latex] is [latex]T = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex]. Step 2: Calculate [latex] |x(t)|^2 [/latex] The signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] is real, so we can calculate [latex]|x(t)|^2[/latex] directly: [latex]|x(t)|^2 = (1 + 2 \cos(2\pi t) + 2 \cos(4\pi t) + 2 \cos(6\pi t))^2[/latex] Expanding the square: [latex]|x(t)|^2 = 1 + 4 \cos(2\pi t) + 4 \cos(4\pi t) + 4 \cos(6\pi t) + 4 \cos^2(2\pi t) + 4 \cos(2\pi t) \cos(4\pi t) + \ldots[/latex] Step 3: Integrate over one period We now need to compute the integral of [latex]|x(t)|^2[/latex] over one period [latex]T = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex]. Many of the cross-term integrals, like [latex]\int_0^T \cos(2\pi t) \cos(4\pi t) dt[/latex], will be zero due to the orthogonality property of the cosine functions. For the terms that do not vanish: [latex] \int_0^T 1 , dt = T = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex] [latex] \int_0^T \cos^2(2\pi t) , dt = \frac{1}{2} T = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] (using the identity [latex]\cos^2(x) = \frac{1 + \cos(2x)}{2}[/latex]) Similarly, [latex] \int_0^T \cos^2(4\pi t) , dt = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] and [latex] \int_0^T \cos^2(6\pi t) , dt = \frac{1}{2}[/latex]. Step 4: Sum up the integrals After evaluating the integrals and summing them up, the result of the integral is: [latex] \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 , dt = 1 + 4 \times \frac{1}{2} + 4 \times \frac{1}{2} + 4 \times \frac{1}{2} = 1 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 7[/latex]. Step 5: Compute the final result Now, we divide by the period [latex]T = 1] sec: [latex]\frac{1}{T} \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 , dt = \frac{7}{1} = 7[/latex]. Final Answer: The value of [latex]\frac{1}{T} \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 , dt[/latex] is closest to 7.

If [latex] Y = g(X) = X^2 [/latex], then [latex] X = \sqrt{Y} [/latex] (since [latex] X > 0 [/latex]), and the PDF of [latex] Y [/latex] is: [latex] P_Y(y) = P_X(x) \cdot \left| \frac{dx}{dy} \right| [/latex] We know [latex] x = \sqrt{y} [/latex], so: [latex] \frac{dx}{dy} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} [/latex] Therefore: [latex] P_Y(y) = P_X(\sqrt{y}) \cdot \left| \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} \right| = 1 \cdot \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} [/latex], for [latex] y \in (0, 1] [/latex] Step 3: So the correct PDF of [latex] Y [/latex] is: [latex] P_Y(y) = \begin{cases} \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{y}}, & y \in (0, 1] \ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} [/latex] Final Answer: (A) [latex] \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} [/latex], for [latex] y \in (0, 1] [/latex]

question: Question 30 Let continuous-time signals [latex]{x}_{1}({t})[/latex] and [latex]{x}_{2}({t})[/latex] be [latex]{x}_{1}({t})= \begin{cases}1, & {t} \in[0,1] \\ 2-{t}, & {t} \in[1,2] \text { and } \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}[/latex] [latex]{x}_{2}({t})= \begin{cases}{t}, & {t} \in[0,1] \\ 2-{t}, & {t} \in[1,2] \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}[/latex] Consider the convolution [latex]{y}({t})={x}_{1}({t}){*} {x}_{2}({t})[/latex]. Question 31 Let [latex]\mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s})=\frac{1}{(\mathrm{s}+1)(\mathrm{s}+2)}[/latex]. Then the closed-loop system shown in the figure below, is
solution: Step 1: Open-loop transfer function: [latex] G(s) = \frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex], So the forward path becomes: [latex] K(s-1)G(s) = \frac{K(s-1)}{(s+1)(s+2)} [/latex] Step 2: Closed-loop transfer function (unity feedback): [latex] T(s) = \frac{K(s-1)G(s)}{1 + K(s-1)G(s)} = \frac{K(s-1)}{(s+1)(s+2) + K(s-1)} [/latex] Step 3: Characteristic equation: [latex] (s+1)(s+2) + K(s-1) = 0 [/latex] Compute: [latex] s^2 + 3s + 2 + K(s - 1) = 0 [/latex] [latex] s^2 + 3s + 2 + Ks - K = 0 [/latex] [latex] s^2 + (3 + K)s + (2 - K) = 0 [/latex] Step 4: Apply Routh-Hurwitz criterion: For a second-order system [latex] s^2 + a_1 s + a_0 [/latex] to be stable, both coefficients must be positive: [latex] a_1 = 3 + K > 0 \Rightarrow \text{always true for } K > -3 [/latex] [latex] a_0 = 2 - K > 0 \Rightarrow K < 2 [/latex] So the system is stable for [latex] K < 2 [/latex], and unstable for [latex] K \geq 2 [/latex]. Final Answer: (B) unstable for all [latex] K \geq 2 [/latex]

question: Question 32 The continuous-time unit impulse signal is applied as an input to a continuous-time linear timeinvariant system [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex]. The output is observed to be the continuous-time unit step signal [latex]u(t)[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: Step 1: Given that the output of system [latex] \mathcal{S} [/latex] for an input [latex] \delta(t) [/latex] (unit impulse) is [latex] u(t) [/latex] (unit step), So, the impulse response of the system is: [latex] h(t) = u(t) [/latex] Step 2: A system is Bounded Input Bounded Output (BIBO) stable if its impulse response is absolutely integrable: [latex] \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} |h(t)| dt < \infty [/latex] Here, [latex] h(t) = u(t) [/latex], so: [latex] \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} |u(t)| dt = \int_{0}^{\infty} 1 , dt = \infty [/latex] Hence, the system is not BIBO stable. Step 3: If a system is not BIBO stable, then there exists at least one bounded input that will produce an unbounded output. Final Answer: (B) It is possible to find a bounded input signal which when applied to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] results in an unbounded output signal.

options.A: very bounded input signal applied to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] results in a bounded output signal.
options.B: It is possible to find a bounded input signal which when applied to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] results in an unbounded output signal.
options.C: On applying any input signal to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex], the output signal is always bounded.
options.D: On applying any input signal to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] the output signal is always unbounded.

question: Question 34 A DC series motor with negligible series resistance is running at a certain speed driving a load, where the load torque varies as cube of the speed. The motor is fed from a 400 V DC source and draws 40 A armature current. Assume linear magnetic circuit. The external resistance, in [latex]\Omega[/latex], that must be connected in series with the armature to reduce the speed of the motor by half, is closest to
solution: [latex]T_{e m} \propto I_{a}{ }^{2}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}} \propto \mathrm{N}^{3}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a}}{ }^{2} \propto \mathrm{~N}^{3}[/latex] [latex]\left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 2}}{\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 1}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{N}_{2}}{\mathrm{~N}_{1}}\right)^{3}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 2}^{2}=40^{2} \times \frac{1}{8}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 2}=14.142 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{b} 2}=400-14.14\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{ex}}\right)[/latex] [latex]\therefore \frac{N_{2}}{N_{1}}=\frac{E_{b 2}}{E_{b 1}} \times \frac{\phi_{1}}{\phi_{2}}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}=\frac{400-14.14\left(R_{\text {ex }}\right)}{400} \times \frac{40}{14.142}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{ex}}=23.28 \Omega[/latex]

Question 36 The 3-phase modulating waveforms [latex]({v}_{{a}}({t}), {v}_{{b}}({t}) [/latex] and [latex]{v}_{{c}}({t}) )[/latex], used in sinusoidal PWM in a Voltage Source Inverter (VSI) are [latex]{v}_{{a}}({t})=0.8 \sin (\omega {t}) {V}[/latex] [latex]{v}_{{b}}({t})=0.8 \sin \left(\omega {t}-\frac{2 \pi}{3}\right) {V}[/latex] [latex]{V}_{{c}}({t})=0.8 \sin \left(\omega {t}+\frac{2 \pi}{3}\right) {V}[/latex] Where [latex]\omega=2 \pi \times 40 {rad} / {s}[/latex] is the fundamental frequency. The modulating waveforms are compared with a 10 kHz triangular carrier whose magnitude varies between +1 and -1 . The VSI has a DC link voltage of 600 V and feeds a star connected motor. The per phase fundamental RMS motor voltage, in volts, is closest to
solution: Step 1: The modulation index [latex] m_a [/latex] is defined as: [latex] m_a = \frac{V_m}{V_{\text{tri}}} [/latex], where [latex] V_m = 0.8 [/latex] (peak of sine) and [latex] V_{\text{tri}} = 1 [/latex] (peak of carrier) So: [latex] m_a = 0.8 [/latex] Step 2: In sinusoidal PWM for a 3-phase VSI, the peak value of fundamental line-to-neutral voltage is: [latex] V_{an}^{\text{peak}} = m_a \cdot \frac{V_{dc}}{2} = 0.8 \cdot \frac{600}{2} = 240, \text{V} [/latex] Step 3: Convert peak to RMS for a sine wave: [latex] V_{an}^{\text{rms}} = \frac{V_{an}^{\text{peak}}}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{240}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 169.71, \text{V} [/latex]

question: Question 37 An ideal sinusoidal voltage source [latex]\mathrm{V}(\mathrm{t})=230 \sqrt{2} \sin (2 \pi \times 50 \mathrm{t}) \mathrm{V}[/latex] feeds an ideal inductor L through an ideal SCR with firing angle [latex]\alpha=0^{\circ}[/latex]. If [latex]L=100 \mathrm{mH}[/latex], then the peak of the inductor current, in ampere, is closest to
solution: Step 1: Given: [latex] v(t) = 230\sqrt{2} \sin(2\pi \cdot 50 t) [/latex] [latex] \omega = 2\pi \cdot 50 = 100\pi [/latex] [latex] L = 100, \text{mH} = 0.1, \text{H} [/latex] Firing angle [latex] \alpha = 0^\circ [/latex], i.e., conduction starts at [latex] t = 0 [/latex] Step 2: The current through an inductor is given by: [latex] i(t) = \frac{1}{L} \int_0^t v(\tau), d\tau = \frac{1}{L} \int_0^t 230\sqrt{2} \sin(100\pi \tau), d\tau [/latex] Step 3: Integrating: [latex] i(t) = \frac{230\sqrt{2}}{L \cdot 100\pi} (1 - \cos(100\pi t)) [/latex] Step 4: The peak of this expression occurs when [latex] \cos(100\pi t) = -1 [/latex] Then: [latex] i_{\text{peak}} = \frac{230\sqrt{2}}{0.1 \cdot 100\pi} \cdot (1 - (-1)) = \frac{230\sqrt{2}}{10\pi} \cdot 2 [/latex] Calculate it: [latex] i_{\text{peak}} = \frac{2 \cdot 230\sqrt{2}}{10\pi} = \frac{460 \cdot 1.4142}{10\pi} \approx \frac{651}{31.4159} \approx 20.72, \text{A} [/latex]

question: Question 40 An air filled cylindrical capacitor (capacitance [latex]\mathrm{C}_{0}[/latex] ) of length [latex]L[/latex], with [latex]a[/latex] and [latex]b[/latex] as its inner and outer radii, respectively, consists of two coaxial conducting surfaces. Its cross-sectional view is shown in Fig. (i). In order to increase the capacitance, a dielectric material of relative permittivity [latex]\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}[/latex] is inserted inside [latex]50 \%[/latex] of the annular region as shown in Fig. (ii). The value of [latex]\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}[/latex] for which the capacitance of the capacitor in Fig. (ii), becomes [latex]5 \mathrm{C}_{0}[/latex] is
solution: Step 1: Capacitance of a cylindrical capacitor The capacitance of a coaxial cylindrical capacitor filled with dielectric of permittivity [latex] \varepsilon [/latex] is given by: [latex] C = \frac{2\pi \varepsilon L}{\ln(b/a)} [/latex] So, for Fig. (i) with air throughout (i.e., permittivity [latex] \varepsilon_0 [/latex]): [latex] C_0 = \frac{2\pi \varepsilon_0 L}{\ln(b/a)} [/latex] Step 2: For Fig. (ii) The cross-section is split into two equal parts (in parallel): One half is filled with air [latex] \varepsilon_0 [/latex] The other half is filled with dielectric [latex] \varepsilon_r \varepsilon_0 [/latex] Since they are in parallel, total capacitance is: [latex] C = \frac{1}{2} C_0 + \frac{1}{2} \varepsilon_r C_0 = \frac{C_0}{2}(1 + \varepsilon_r) [/latex] We are given that [latex] C = 5C_0 [/latex]. So: [latex] \frac{C_0}{2}(1 + \varepsilon_r) = 5C_0 [/latex] Divide both sides by [latex] C_0 [/latex]: [latex] \frac{1 + \varepsilon_r}{2} = 5 [/latex] [latex] 1 + \varepsilon_r = 10 \Rightarrow \varepsilon_r = 9 [/latex] Final Answer: (C) 9

question: Question 41 Let [latex]{a}_{{R}}[/latex] be the unit radial vector in the spherical co-ordinate system. For which of the following value(s) of [latex]n[/latex], the divergence of the radial vector field [latex]f(R)=a_{R} \frac{1}{R^{n}}[/latex] is independent of [latex]R[/latex] ?
solution:
We use the divergence formula for a purely radial vector field in spherical coordinates: [latex]
\nabla \cdot \left( \frac{1}{R^n} \mathbf{a}_R \right)
= \frac{1}{R^2} \frac{d}{dR} \left( R^2 \cdot \frac{1}{R^n} \right)
= \frac{1}{R^2} \frac{d}{dR} \left( R^{2-n} \right)
= \frac{1}{R^2} \cdot (2 - n) R^{1 - n}
= (2 - n) R^{-1 - n}
[/latex] We want this expression to be independent of [latex] R [/latex], so the power of [latex] R [/latex] must be zero: [latex]
-1 - n = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad n = -1
[/latex] So clearly [latex] n = -1 [/latex] is one valid value. Now check another special case: Case: [latex] n = 2 [/latex] Try plugging [latex] n = 2 [/latex] directly into the divergence expression: [latex]
\nabla \cdot \left( \frac{1}{R^2} \mathbf{a}_R \right)
= \frac{1}{R^2} \frac{d}{dR} \left( R^2 \cdot \frac{1}{R^2} \right)
= \frac{1}{R^2} \frac{d}{dR} (1) = 0
[/latex] So the divergence is zero, which is also independent of [latex] R [/latex].

solution:
Step 1: Direction vector and its unit vector The direction vector from origin to point (1, 2) is: [latex] \vec{u} = \langle 1, 2 angle [/latex] Magnitude of this vector is: [latex] |\vec{u}| = \sqrt{1^2 + 2^2} = \sqrt{5} [/latex] Unit vector in the given direction is: [latex] \hat{u} = \left\langle  rac{1}{\sqrt{5}},  rac{2}{\sqrt{5}} ightangle [/latex] Step 2: Compute the gradient of V(x, y) [latex] 
abla V = \left\langle  rac{\partial V}{\partial x},  rac{\partial V}{\partial y} ightangle = \left\langle 2x + 1, 2y ightangle [/latex] At the origin (0, 0), the gradient becomes: [latex] 
abla V(0, 0) = \langle 1, 0 angle [/latex] Step 3: Compute the directional derivative Directional derivative of V in the direction of unit vector [latex] \hat{u} [/latex] is: [latex] D_{\hat{u}} V =

question: Question 44 Consider ordinary differential equations given by [latex]\dot{x}_{1}({t})=2 {x}_{2}({t}) [/latex] [latex] \dot{{x}}_{2}({t})={r}({t})[/latex] with initial conditions [latex]{x}_{1}(0)=1[/latex] and [latex]{x}_{2}(0)=0[/latex]. If [latex]r(t)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}1, & t \geq 0 \\ 0, & t < 0\end{array}\right.[/latex], then at [latex]t=1, x_{1}(t)=[/latex] ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Given [latex]\frac{{dx}_{1}}{{dt}}=2 {x}_{2} \quad ...(1)[/latex] [latex]\frac{{dx}_{2}}{{dt}}={r}({t}), \quad {r}({t})=\left\{\begin{array}{l}1: {t} \geq 0 \\ 0: {t} < 0 \end{array}\right.[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{{dx}_{2}}{{dt}}=1[/latex] for [latex]{t} \geq 0 \quad ...(2)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow {x}_{2}={t}+{c}  \quad ...(3)[/latex] Given [latex]x_{2}(0)=0[/latex] (3) [latex]\Rightarrow 0=0+c \Rightarrow c=0[/latex] [latex]\therefore {x}_{2}={t}[/latex] From (1) [latex]\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=2 t[/latex] [latex]
\Rightarrow {x}_{1}=\frac{2 {t}^{2}}{2}+{K} \quad ...(4)
[/latex] Given [latex]{x}_{1}(0)=1:(4) \Rightarrow 1=0+{K}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow {K}=1[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] From (4) [latex]{x}_{1}={t}^{2}+1[/latex] Now [latex]{X}_{1}(1)=1+1=2[/latex]

question: Question 45 Let [latex]C[/latex] be a clockwise oriented closed curve in the complex plane defined by [latex]|z|=1[/latex]. Further, let [latex]f(z)=j z[/latex] be a complex function, where [latex]j=\sqrt{-1}[/latex]. Then, [latex]\oint_{{C}} {f}({z}) {dz}=[/latex] ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Step 1: Express the function We are given [latex] f(z) = jz [/latex], and we want to compute: [latex] \oint_C jz , dz [/latex] Step 2: Use properties of contour integrals [latex] j = \sqrt{-1} [/latex] is a constant, so it can be pulled out of the integral: [latex] \oint_C jz , dz = j \oint_C z , dz [/latex] Step 3: Recall the standard result For a closed contour [latex] C [/latex] enclosing the origin (like [latex] |z| = 1 [/latex]), [latex] \oint_C z , dz = 0 [/latex] because [latex] z [/latex] is an analytic function inside and on [latex] C [/latex]. Step 4: Apply the result [latex] \oint_C f(z) , dz = j \cdot 0 = 0 [/latex]

question: Question 46 The op-amps in the following circuit are ideal. The voltage gain of the circuit is ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Step 1: Recognize the configuration The circuit consists of two inverting amplifier stages connected in cascade. Step 2: Analyze the first op-amp For an inverting amplifier, the gain is: [latex] A_{v1} = -\frac{R_f}{R_{in}} [/latex] From the diagram: Input resistor: [latex] R_{in1} = 10\ \text{k}\Omega [/latex] Feedback resistor: [latex] R_{f1} = 10\ \text{k}\Omega [/latex] So, [latex] A_{v1} = -\frac{10}{10} = -1 [/latex] Step 3: Analyze the second op-amp This stage is also an inverting amplifier: Input resistor: [latex] R_{in2} = 10\ \text{k}\Omega [/latex] Feedback resistor: [latex] R_{f2} = 20\ \text{k}\Omega [/latex] (notice the input is tapped from the junction between two 10 kΩ resistors in series, so it's effectively 10 kΩ from input and 10 kΩ in feedback, making total feedback resistance = 10k + 10k = 20k) So, [latex] A_{v2} = -\frac{20}{10} = -2 [/latex] Step 4: Total Gain Overall voltage gain is: [latex] A_v = A_{v1} \cdot A_{v2} = (-1) \cdot (-2) = 2 [/latex] Final Answer: 2

question: Question 47 The switch (S) closes at [latex]\mathrm{t}=0 \mathrm{sec}[/latex]. The time, in sec, the capacitor takes to charge to 50 V is ___________ (round off to one decimal place).

Question 48 In an experiment to measure the active power drawn by a single-phase RL Load connected to an AC source through a [latex]2 \Omega[/latex] resistor, three voltmeters are connected as shown in the figure below. The voltmeter readings are as follows: 
[latex]\mathrm{V}_{\text {source }}=200 \mathrm{~V}, \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{R}}=9 \mathrm{~V}, \mathrm{~V}_{\text {Load }}=199 \mathrm{~V}[/latex]. Assuming perfect resistors and ideal voltmeters, the Loadactive power measured in this experiment, in W, is
___________ (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Here [latex]|\mathrm{I}|=\frac{\left|\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{R}}\right|}{2}=\frac{9}{2}=4.5 \mathrm{~A}[\mathrm{RMS}][/latex] From resultant of vectors's formulae

[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{V}_{\text {source }} & =\sqrt{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{R}}^{2}+\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{Load}}^{2}+2 \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{R}} \cdot \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{Load}} \cos \phi_{\mathrm{L}}} \\
200 & =\sqrt{9^{2}+199^{2}+2(9)(199) \cos \phi_{\mathrm{L}}} \\
\cos \phi_{\mathrm{L}} & =\frac{(200)^{2}-9^{2}-199^{2}}{2(9)(199)}=\frac{318}{3582}=0.08877(\mathrm{lag}) \\
\mathrm{P} & =\left|\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{Load}}\right| \mathrm{I} \mid \cos \phi_{\mathrm{L}} \\
& =|199|\left|\frac{9}{2}\right|(0.08877) \\
\mathrm{P} & =79.5 \mathrm{~W}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 50 The steady state capacitor current of a conventional DC-DC buck converter, working in CCM, is shown in one switching cycle. If the input voltage is 30 V , the value of the inductor used, in mH, is ___________ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{S}}=30 \mathrm{~V}, \mathrm{~L}=?[/latex] [latex]\Delta \mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{c}}=0.1-(-0.1)=0.2 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{D}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{ON}}}{\mathrm{T}}=\frac{30 \times 10^{-6}}{\left(\mathrm{~T}_{\mathrm{ON}}+\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{OFF}}\right)}=\frac{30 \times 10^{-6}}{50 \times 10^{-6}}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \mathrm{D}=0.6[/latex] [latex]\Delta \mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{L}}=\Delta \mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{C}}[/latex] [latex]\frac{\mathrm{D}(1-\mathrm{D}) \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}} \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{L}}=0.2[/latex] [latex]\frac{0.6 \times(1-0.6) \times 30 \times 50 \times 10^{-6}}{\mathrm{~L}}=0.2[/latex] [latex]\therefore \mathrm{L}=1.8 \mathrm{mH}[/latex]

question:
Question 51 An ideal low pass filter has frequency response given by [latex]
H(j \omega)= \begin{cases}1, & |\omega| \leq 200 \pi \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
[/latex] Let [latex]h(t)[/latex] be its time domain representation. Then 
[latex]h(0)=[/latex] ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).

solution: Step 1: Write the state matrix [latex] A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \ -2 & -3 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Step 2: Find the characteristic equation We compute the determinant of [latex] sI - A [/latex]: [latex] \det(sI - A) = \left| \begin{array}{cc} s & -1 \ 2 & s + 3 \end{array} \right| = s(s + 3) - (-2)(1) = s^2 + 3s + 2 [/latex] Step 3: Find the roots of the characteristic equation [latex] s^2 + 3s + 2 = 0 [/latex] Factorizing: [latex] (s + 1)(s + 2) = 0 \Rightarrow s = -1, -2 [/latex] Step 4: Compute the sum of the magnitudes of the poles [latex] |{-1}| + |{-2}| = 1 + 2 = 3 [/latex]

question: Question 53 Using shunt capacitors, the power factor of a 3-phase, 4 kV induction motor (drawing 390 kVA at 0.77 pf lag ) is to be corrected to 0.85 pf lag. The line current of the capacitor bank, in A, is ___________ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: Given: Line voltage of motor: [latex] V_L = 4000\ \text{V} [/latex] Apparent power: [latex] S = 390\ \text{kVA} [/latex] Initial power factor: [latex] \cos\phi_1 = 0.77\ (\text{lagging}) [/latex] Target power factor: [latex] \cos\phi_2 = 0.85\ (\text{lagging}) [/latex] Step 1: Compute the active power (real power) [latex] P = S \cdot \cos\phi_1 = 390 \cdot 0.77 = 300.3\ \text{kW} [/latex] Step 2: Compute reactive power before correction [latex] Q_1 = \sqrt{S^2 - P^2} = \sqrt{390^2 - 300.3^2} = \sqrt{152100 - 90180.09} = \sqrt{61919.91} \approx 248.8\ \text{kVAR} [/latex] Step 3: Compute reactive power after correction New apparent power [latex] S_2 = \frac{P}{\cos\phi_2} = \frac{300.3}{0.85} \approx 353.3\ \text{kVA} [/latex] [latex] Q_2 = \sqrt{S_2^2 - P^2} = \sqrt{353.3^2 - 300.3^2} = \sqrt{124821.89 - 90180.09} = \sqrt{34641.8} \approx 186.0\ \text{kVAR} [/latex] Step 4: Required reactive power by capacitor bank [latex] Q_c = Q_1 - Q_2 = 248.8 - 186.0 = 62.8\ \text{kVAR} [/latex] Step 5: Convert to line current In a 3-phase system, reactive power is: [latex] Q = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L \Rightarrow I_L = \frac{Q}{\sqrt{3} V_L} [/latex] [latex] I_L = \frac{62.8 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \cdot 4000} = \frac{62800}{6928.2} \approx 9.1\ \text{A} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{9.1\ \text{A}} [/latex]

question: Question 54 Two units, rated at 100 MW and 150 MW , are enabled for economic load dispatch. When the overall incremental cost is 10,000 Rs./MWh, the units are dispatched to 50 MW and 80 MW respectively. At an overall incremental cost of [latex]10,600 \mathrm{Rs} . / \mathrm{MWh}[/latex], the power output of the units are 80 MW and 92 MW , respectively. The total plant MW-output (without overloading any unit) at an overall incremental cost of 11,800 Rs./MWh is ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Let’s define: Unit 1 outputs:
At 10,000 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_1 = 50\ \text{MW} [/latex]
At 10,600 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_1 = 80\ \text{MW} [/latex] Unit 2 outputs:
At 10,000 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_2 = 80\ \text{MW} [/latex]
At 10,600 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_2 = 92\ \text{MW} [/latex] We are to find outputs at 11,800 Rs./MWh using extrapolation for both units (assuming linearity of power vs incremental cost curve). Step 1: Find slope of output with respect to cost for each unit Unit 1 slope:
[latex] \frac{80 - 50}{10,600 - 10,000} = \frac{30}{600} = 0.05\ \text{MW per Rs./MWh} [/latex] Unit 2 slope:
[latex] \frac{92 - 80}{10,600 - 10,000} = \frac{12}{600} = 0.02\ \text{MW per Rs./MWh} [/latex] Step 2: Extrapolate to 11,800 Rs./MWh Cost increase: [latex] 11,800 - 10,600 = 1,200\ \text{Rs./MWh} [/latex] Unit 1 output:
[latex] P_1 = 80 + (0.05)(1200) = 80 + 60 = 140\ \text{MW} [/latex]
(but Unit 1 is rated for 100 MW max ⇒ limit to 100 MW) Unit 2 output:
[latex] P_2 = 92 + (0.02)(1200) = 92 + 24 = 116\ \text{MW} [/latex]
(but Unit 2 is rated for 150 MW ⇒ no limit hit) Step 3: Total Output [latex] P_{\text{total}} = 100 + 116 = \boxed{216\ \text{MW}} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{216} [/latex]

question: Question 55 A controller [latex]D(s)[/latex] of the form [latex]\left(1+K_{D} s\right)[/latex] is to be designed for the plant [latex]G(s)=\frac{1000 \sqrt{2}}{s(s+10)^{2}}[/latex] as shown in the figure. The value of [latex]\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}}[/latex] that yields a phase margin of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] at the gain cross-over frequency of [latex]10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex] is ___________ (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Given phase margin [P.M] [latex]=45^{\circ}[/latex] at gain cross over frequency [latex]\left[\omega_{\mathrm{gc}}\right]=10[/latex] O.L.T.F with controller [latex]=\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathrm{s})=\mathrm{D}(\mathrm{s}) . \mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s})[/latex] [latex]
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathrm{~s})=\frac{\left[1+\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}} \mathrm{~S}\right] \times 1000 \sqrt{2}}{\mathrm{~s}[\mathrm{~s}+10]^{2}} \\
\text { P.M }=180^{\circ}+\left.\angle \mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathrm{~s})\right|_{\omega=\omega_{\mathrm{gc}}} \\
\text { Given P.M }=45^{\circ} \text { at } \omega_{\mathrm{gc}}=10 \\
45^{\circ}=180^{\circ}+\angle \frac{1000 \sqrt{2}\left[1+\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}} \mathrm{~s}\right.}{} \mathrm{s}[\mathrm{~s}+10]^{2} \\
45^{\circ}=\left[180^{\circ}-90^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{gc}} \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}}{1}\right]-2 \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{gc}}=10}{10}\right)\right]_{\mathrm{\omega gc}}=10 \\
45^{\circ}=90^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1}\left[10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}\right]-2 \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{10}{10}\right) \\
45^{\circ}=90^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1}\left[10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}\right]-2 \times 45^{\circ} \\
\tan ^{-1}\left[10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}\right]=45^{\circ} \\
10 \mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{D}}={\tan 45^{\circ}=1}\\{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}}=\frac{1}{10}=0.1}
\end{gathered}
[/latex]

Question 58 The relationship between two variables [latex]x[/latex] and [latex]y[/latex] is given by [latex]x + py + q = 0[/latex] and is shown in the figure. Find the values of [latex]p[/latex] and [latex]q[/latex]. Note: The figure shown is representative.  ]
solution: The equation is of the form: [latex]x + py + q = 0[/latex] Rewriting it in slope-intercept form: [latex]py = -x - q[/latex] [latex]y = -\frac{1}{p}x - \frac{q}{p}[/latex] This is of the form [latex]y = mx + c[/latex] where slope [latex]m = -\frac{1}{p}[/latex] and intercept [latex]c = -\frac{q}{p}[/latex] From the figure: The y-intercept is [latex]c = 4[/latex] (line passes through point (0, 4)) The line passes through another point (2, 8), so slope is: [latex]m = \frac{8 - 4}{2 - 0} = \frac{4}{2} = 2[/latex] Equating this with [latex]-\frac{1}{p}[/latex], [latex]-\frac{1}{p} = 2 \Rightarrow p = -\frac{1}{2}[/latex] Now use y-intercept formula: [latex]-\frac{q}{p} = 4[/latex] Substitute [latex]p = -\frac{1}{2}[/latex]: [latex]-\frac{q}{-\frac{1}{2}} = 4 \Rightarrow \frac{q}{\frac{1}{2}} = 4 \Rightarrow q = 2[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]p = -\frac{1}{2}, \quad q = 2[/latex]

Question 63 Scores obtained by two students P and Q in seven courses are given in the table below. Based on the information given in the table, which one of the following statements is INCORRECT? [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline
P & 22 & 89 & 50 & 45 & 78 & 60 & 39\\
\hline
Q & 35 & 65 & 60 & 56 & 81 & 45 & 50 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution: Step 1: Calculate average score of P and Q P total = [latex]22 + 89 + 50 + 45 + 78 + 60 + 39 = 383[/latex] Average of P = [latex]\frac{383}{7} \approx 54.71[/latex] Q total = [latex]35 + 65 + 60 + 56 + 81 + 45 + 50 = 392[/latex] Average of Q = [latex]\frac{392}{7} = 56[/latex] So, average of P is less than average of Q ->(A) is correct. Step 2: Calculate median score Sorted scores: P: 22, 39, 45, 50, 60, 78, 89 → Median = 50 Q: 35, 45, 50, 56, 60, 65, 81 → Median = 56 So, (B) is incorrect (they are not the same). Step 3: Difference between max and min P: Max = 89, Min = 22 → Difference = [latex]89 - 22 = 67[/latex] Q: Max = 81, Min = 35 → Difference = [latex]81 - 35 = 46[/latex] 67 > 46 → (C) is correct. Step 4: Check if average and median of Q are same Average of Q = 56, Median of Q = 56 → (D) is correct. Final Answer: The INCORRECT statement is: (B)

options.A: Average score of P is less than the average score of Q.
options.B: Median score of P is same as the median score of Q .
options.C: Difference between the maximum and minimum scores of P is greater than the difference between the maximum and minimum scores of Q .
options.D: Median score and the average score of Q are same.

question: Question 64 Spheres of unit diameter are centered at ( [latex]l, {m}, {n}[/latex] ) where [latex]l, {m}[/latex], and [latex]n [/latex] take every possible integer values. The distance between two spheres is computed from the center of one sphere to the center of the other sphere. For a given sphere, [latex]x [/latex] is the distance to its nearest sphere and [latex]y [/latex] is the distance to its next nearest sphere. The value of [latex]\frac{y}{x}[/latex] is:
solution: Spheres are centered at all points [latex](l, m, n)[/latex] where [latex]l, m, n \in \mathbb{Z}[/latex] (i.e., all integer coordinates). That means the spheres are placed in a cubic lattice with unit spacing between centers. Step 1: Nearest sphere distance [latex]x[/latex] Each sphere has 6 immediate neighbors at a distance of 1 unit along the directions [latex]\pm x[/latex], [latex]\pm y[/latex], and [latex]\pm z[/latex]. So, [latex]x = 1[/latex] Step 2: Next nearest sphere distance [latex]y[/latex] The next nearest neighbors are along the diagonals of the faces (e.g., from (0,0,0) to (1,1,0)). Their distance is: [latex]y = \sqrt{(1)^2 + (1)^2} = \sqrt{2}[/latex] Step 3: Compute [latex]\frac{y}{x}[/latex] [latex]\frac{y}{x} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{1} = \sqrt{2}[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\boxed{\sqrt{2}}[/latex]

question: Question 65 In the triangle PQR, the lengths of PT and TR are in the ratio of [latex]3: 2[/latex]. ST is parallel to QR. Two semicircles are drawn with PS and PQ as diameters, as shown in the figure. Which one of the following statements is true about the shaded area PQS? Note: The figure shown is representative.
solution: Step 1: Let us assume PQ = 5 units Given the ratio [latex]PT : TR = 3 : 2[/latex], then [latex]PT = 3[/latex] units and [latex]TR = 2[/latex] units, so total [latex]PR = PT + TR = 5[/latex] units. Since [latex]ST \parallel QR[/latex] and [latex]T[/latex] lies on [latex]PR[/latex], by Basic Proportionality Theorem: [latex]\frac{PS}{PQ} = \frac{PT}{PR} = \frac{3}{5}[/latex] So, [latex]PS = \frac{3}{5} \cdot PQ[/latex] Step 2: Area of semicircle is proportional to square of diameter Let the diameter [latex]PQ = d[/latex]. Then the area of the semicircle with diameter [latex]PQ[/latex] is: [latex]A_{PQ} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{\pi d^2}{4} = \frac{\pi d^2}{8}[/latex] Now, [latex]PS = \frac{3}{5} d[/latex], so area of semicircle on PS: [latex]A_{PS} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{\pi (3d/5)^2}{4} = \frac{\pi d^2}{8} \cdot \frac{9}{25} = A_{PQ} \cdot \frac{9}{25}[/latex] Step 3: Shaded Area = Area of semicircle on PQ − Area of semicircle on PS [latex]A_{\text{shaded}} = A_{PQ} - A_{PS} = A_{PQ} \left(1 - \frac{9}{25}\right) = A_{PQ} \cdot \frac{16}{25}[/latex] Now convert the shaded area as a multiple of the semicircle on PS: [latex]\frac{A_{\text{shaded}}}{A_{PS}} = \frac{A_{PQ} \cdot \frac{16}{25}}{A_{PQ} \cdot \frac{9}{25}} = \frac{16}{9}[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\boxed{\frac{16}{9}}[/latex] times the area of the semicircle with diameter [latex]PS[/latex]

options.A: The shaded area is [latex]\frac{16}{9}[/latex] times the area of the semicircle with the diameter PS.
options.B: The shaded area is equal to the area of the semicircle with the diameter PS.
options.C: The shaded area is [latex]\frac{14}{9}[/latex] times the area of the semicircle with the diameter PS.
options.D: The shaded area is [latex]\frac{14}{25}[/latex] times the area of the semicircle with the diameter PQ.
